content:
Hi, my name is Rick Hu. I started to learn Lean (Lean 4) a couple of months ago. I am reading the excellent books Theorem Proving in Lean 4 and Functional Programming in Lean. I use emacs for Lean.

I have two questions to ask here

  1. In emacs, given a type or a namespace, is there a way to look up available functions for the type or namespace? Something similar to python's dir.
  2. In emacs, for any operator, such as ▸, is there a way to look up its definition, similar to using #check?

Thanks,
Rick

Welcome! If nobody wants to give an answer, it must mean you're the last emacs user. Everyone else seem to have migrated to VS Code and Neovim (including myself).

Rick Hu said:

  1. In emacs, given a type or a namespace, is there a way to look up available functions for the type or namespace? Something similar to python's dir.

I don't think there is an official way to do this. You can try typing MyNamespace. and seeing if autocomplete picks up anything. A more advanced approach is to use the Lean search engine Loogle: https://loogle.lean-fro.org/

  1. In emacs, for any operator, such as ▸, is there a way to look up its definition, similar to using #check?

The standard go-to-definition command should also work for notation.

Thanks! :smile:

I did more search, and found these solutions for Emacs

  1. Emacs lean4-mode uses lsp-mode, which already supports completion-at-point. For popup to show up, I need to install Emacs package company to turn on the company minor mode.
  2. Emacs lsp-mode also supports these functions lsp-find-definition and lsp-find-reference.
Rick Hu has marked this topic as resolved.
